There is no need to reach a breaking point. We all agree that the lower the debt-to-GDP ratio the better. We should constantly be thinking of ways to reduce it (not merely the debt at the expense of GDP).

Furthermore, macroeconomics is not even remotely as difficult as algebra or calculus. It is definitely not rocket science.

As you obviously know, it is not the absolute value of the debt that is important, but the debt-to-GDP ratio. This is the most important variable investors consider when buying the newly issued bonds that roll over maturing debt.

It is also important to understand the relationship between deficit and debt: this year's deficit is next year's debt. It is impossible to control the debt by imposing a post-facto debt ceiling. When a deficit of one dollar is incurred the debt automatically rises by one dollar. The debt can only be controlled by controlling the deficit, not by imposing artificial debt ceilings.

We must also understand that debt is measured in current dollars, whereas GDP is measured in constant dollars. To calculate debt-to-GDP we must correct the debt (down) to constant dollars or GDP (up) to current dollars (which can be done by dividing by 1 minus the "deflator").

In practice, we pay back one dollar of debt incurred in 2003 with one of today's dollars worth 75 2003 cents. With debt at $15 trillion and 3% inflation, almost one-half trillion of the debt is essentially wiped out each year by inflation.

To be continued...

In practice, we pay back 100 cents of debt incurred in 2003 with one of today's dollars worth 75 2003 cents. With debt at $15 trillion and 3% inflation, almost one-half trillion of the debt is essentially wiped out by inflation. And with 3% growth, debt-to-GDP remains essentially constant.

Then we must understand that there is no free lunch: both increasing taxes and reducing spending to reduce the deficit and, therefore, the debt also reduce GDP. Therefore we can easily enter a Greece-like economic death spiral. If we manage to reduce the debt by 1% ($150 billion) at the cost of reducing GDP growth by more than 1% we will all be worse off.

Finally (for now), "ceteris paribus" (everything else being equal), does not hold: any spending cuts, draconian or otherwise, to reduce the deficit will also reduce tax revenues and may also increase government spending (people laid off do not pay taxes but do receive unemployment benefits, etc), so that the predicted deficit reduction will not be obtained. This leads to more deficit reduction measures: the cat chasing its tail syndrome (i.e., Greece).

What we should do is (to be continued)...

I agree that greatly reducing the accessibility of guns, and increasing tracking and training of those who do have guns, are the keys to reducing gun violence in America.

However, it seems obvious to me that no sane person would ever attempt to shoot people by random. I can imagine situations where a mentally healthy person might still choose to commit Murder 1 for personal gain or revenge, for example. But choosing to shoot even one person without a logical (if immoral) reason is an inherently insane act.

That said, a very small percentage of gun murders in America are perpetrated by the mentally ill. I agree that the NRA is using mental illness to distract from the real problem of excessive high-powered guns. I also agree that dichotomies like mentally ill / healthy are artificial. Fact is, human consciousness has inherent instabilities. No one on the planet has perfect mental health. Everyone, without exception, has a breaking point. To label the mentally ill as "the other" is nothing less than a way of convincing ourselves that we're nothing like "them" when in fact we're a lot like them.

Anyone who is the least bit familiar with research on the relationship between mental illness and violence knows full well that this effort to focus attention on the mentally ill as perpetrators of gun violence is nothing other than an attempt to deflect attention from the issue of the widespread availability of high-powered weapons of mass destruction (i.e., assault rifles) by the NRA.

Yes, we should be disturbed by the poor quality of care for those with serious mental disorders, but our tendency to label anyone who picks up a gun and charges into a school or theater as "mentally ill" is a total cop-out. It's a desperate attempt to convince ourselves that these shooters are different from the rest of us, and that if we can just identify them and keep them away from guns, we'll all be safe. This is utter foolishness.
